title: PBQ: Ordering & Sequencing
description: Performance-based ordering questions requiring correct sequencing of processes, stages, and activities. Covers project lifecycle, change control process, Tuckman stages, procurement process, closing activities, risk management, Scrum events, and scope management.

questions.question: Place the project life cycle phases in the correct chronological order, from first to last.
questions.explanation: The project life cycle phases in order: Discovery/Concept (evaluate the idea and build the business case), Initiation (authorize the project with a charter), Planning (define scope, schedule, budget), Execution (perform the work), and Closing (validate deliverables and close out).

questions.question: Place Tuckman's team development stages in the correct sequential order.
questions.explanation: Tuckman's stages: Forming (introductions, low productivity), Storming (conflict, competition for position), Norming (increased productivity, learning to work together), Performing (highest productivity, cohesion), Adjourning (concluding work, disbanding).

questions.question: Place the change control process steps in the correct order.
items: Change control board reviews and decides
correct_order: Change control board reviews and decides
questions.explanation: Change control process: (1) Initiate — submit the change request form. (2) Evaluate — assess the impact on scope, schedule, budget, and quality. (3) Decide — the CCB reviews and approves, delays, or rejects. (4) Communicate — notify the requester and stakeholders of the decision. (5) Implement — execute the approved change.

questions.question: Place the procurement process steps in the correct order.
questions.explanation: Procurement process: (1) Research the market and vendors. (2) Develop the procurement SOW and documents. (3) Distribute the solicitation. (4) Evaluate received proposals against selection criteria. (5) Award the contract to the selected vendor.

questions.question: Place these project closing activities in a logical sequence.
questions.explanation: Closing sequence: (1) Validate all deliverables are accepted. (2) Conduct lessons learned to capture insights. (3) Obtain formal sign-off via the closeout report. (4) Release project resources back to the organization. (5) Archive all project documentation for future reference.

questions.question: Place the risk management steps in the correct order.
items: Document risks in the risk register
correct_order: Document risks in the risk register
questions.explanation: Risk management process: (1) Identify potential risks. (2) Analyze risks using qualitative and/or quantitative methods. (3) Develop response strategies (avoid, mitigate, transfer, accept, etc.). (4) Document everything in the risk register. (5) Monitor and control risks throughout the project.

questions.question: Place the Scrum events in the correct order within a single sprint cycle.
questions.explanation: Scrum events within a sprint: (1) Sprint planning — team selects work for the sprint backlog. (2) Daily Scrum — 15-minute daily status updates throughout the sprint. (3) Sprint review — demonstrate new functionality to stakeholders. (4) Sprint retrospective — team reflects on the sprint and identifies improvements.

questions.question: Place the scope management activities in the correct order for developing a WBS.
items: Identify work packages at the lowest level
correct_order: Identify work packages at the lowest level
questions.explanation: Scope management to WBS: (1) Collect requirements from stakeholders. (2) Define the project scope statement (what is and is not included). (3) Decompose major deliverables into smaller components. (4) Break down to work packages (the lowest, most granular level). (5) Create the WBS dictionary with details about each element.

questions.question: Place the initiation activities in a logical sequence.
questions.explanation: Initiation sequence: (1) Develop the project charter defining project parameters. (2) Get sponsor approval to formally authorize the project. (3) Identify stakeholders and conduct stakeholder analysis. (4) Create the RAM/RACI to assign responsibilities. (5) Conduct the kickoff meeting — marks the end of initiation and the start of project work.

questions.question: Place the agile backlog hierarchy from largest to smallest unit of work.
questions.explanation: Agile backlog hierarchy from largest to smallest: Epic (equivalent to a project, lasts several iterations/months) → Feature (sizeable functionality, larger than a user story) → User story (individual customer requirement or feature) → Task (specific piece of work within a user story).
